sentence: German business software provider SAP SESAP announced impressive numbers in its preliminary fourth-quarter and full-year 2015 results, driven by year-end software license renewals as well as sales of cloud-based software.
The preliminary results come ahead of SAP's scheduled earnings report on Jan 22.
Revenue for the quarter rose 16% year over year to €6.35 billion ($6.95 billion), as both cloud and SAP's core license business displayed exceptional momentum.
SAP's license sales in the fourth quarter rose 15% to €2.15 billion ($2.35 billion), while cloud subscriptions and support revenue grew a whopping 76% to €630 million ($690 million).
Adjusted operating profit for the quarter rose 7% over the prior-year quarter to €2.28 billion ($2.5 billion).
Revenues for full-year 2015 jumped 18% over the previous year to €20.81 billion ($23.1 billion).
SAP also reported record annual operating profits of €6.35 billion ($7.1 billion), up 13% over 2014.
In addition to renewals from existing customers of higher-margin, licensed software and faster-growing Internet-based software, SAP's results also benefited from a relatively weaker euro.
SAP's flagship product - a revamped version of its core business-management software, called S/4 Hana, was a big driver of the company's creditable performance this quarter.
S/4 Hana can run in customers' data centers or as an online service, thus retaining thousands of corporate customers with the company in the midst of an industry-wide shift to cloud computing.
We feel that SAP has charted a very comprehensible road map with S/4 Hana, which has breathed fresh life into sapped customer interest.
SAP revealed that over 2,700 customers are running the new suite now, which is more than double the number at the end of the third quarter.
For 2016, SAP expects operating profit to lie in the range of €6.4 billion to €6.7 billion, compared with €6.35 billion last year.

Last year, SAP outlined its revenue expectations of €26 billion and €28 billion for 2020 with cloud and support revenues between €7.5 billion and €8 billion, which might have seemed a bit optimistic at that time.
However, in light of its recent performance, the numbers are starting to look quite conservative now.
SAP dominates the $30 billion enterprise resource planning software market, with its fellow competitors being Oracle Corp. ORCL and Workday, Inc. WDAY .
It also competes with salesforce.com, inc. CRM in the $26.9 billion market for customer management software.
